Do you think letting someone use drugs

But there are healthcare professionals
who think it's possible
with supervised injection facilities.
These are places where people who struggle

with addiction can legally
inject drugs like opiates.

The main purpose of these
sites is to try to decrease
overdose deaths and bloodborne diseases.

They've been supported by
multiple medical organizations,

including the American
Medical Association,

AIDS United, and the American
Public Health Association.
For the sake of this video,

we're going to call supervised
injection facilities SIFs.

But they also go by
other names like overdose
prevention sites and safe injection sites.
There are over 120 sites in countries

including Switzerland,

Australia, Canada, Norway,
and the Netherlands.

Right now they aren't
considered legal in the U.S.,

but there have been legal
battles over these sites,

which might lead to the SIFs
being federally legalized
in the near future.

Before we go into why they

you need to know how SIFs actually work.

They vary in how the function

But in general, first you
register with the facility

in order to have some
type of identification
for future visits.
Second you would be given clean needles

to prevent diseases like
HIV and Hepatitis C,
but you would have to bring your own drugs

would never provide any.
Then you'd go to an injection station

After injecting, you'd move to a lobby

But before you leave the facility,

And just to make it clear,
an SIF is not the same

as a needle exchange site,
because while they both
give out clean needles and supplies,
at an SIF you can take your drugs on site,
unlike at a needle exchange program.

So now let's look at some
real world examples of SIFs.
The first legal facility was established
in Bern, Switzerland during the 1980s.

It was opened in response to
the country's HIV epidemic.

In 1986 more than 3,000
people tested positive
for HIV in Switzerland.

But in 2017 only 500
people tested positive.

In 2001, Australia opened
its first clinic in Sidney,

which was the first SIF in
the southern hemisphere.

Since it opened, it's
estimated that nearly 6,000
overdose deaths have been prevented.

Vancouver became the first
city in North America
to open SIF in 2003.

After two years there was
a 30% increase in the use

So far there hasn't been

In California, a bill that

This includes building

He's arguing that establishing
a supervised injection

21 of the U.S. Code 856,

for the purpose of

- [McSwain] Your honor, I

- But Safehouse has argued
